Award.AwardTitle: Dilation theory, free semialgebraic geometry and matrix convex sets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many problems in linear systems engineering and branches of mathematics both pure and applied can be modeled by inequalities involving matrices. A given matrix inequality is most useful in applications if it can be converted, through algebraic means, to a new matrix inequality whose solution set has a particularly simple form called "convex." The process of converting a matrix inequality to a convex matrix inequality is currently done on a case-by-case basis, and there is an extensive engineering literature on this subject with successes in particular examples. Continuing work of the principal investigator and his collaborators, a goal of this project is the development of a theory (so-called free real algebraic geometry) to identify exactly those matrix inequalities that can be reduced to obtain convexity and to automate this process when it is possible. A further goal of this project is the development of tools and techniques in the mathematical and scientific fields that underlie the study of free real algebraic geometry. These include semidefinite programming and linear matrix inequalities, subjects that find use in many branches of science and engineering, as well as a branch of mathematics called dilation theory.

A goal of this project is the development of a free (freely noncommutative) analog of semialgebraic geometry with an emphasis on convexity. Semialgebraic geometry is the study of polynomial inequalities. Its free version studies matrix inequalities of the type that arise in engineering systems problems governed by a signal flow diagram. The Riccati inequality is a ubiquitous example. A desired long-term outcome of the project is a practical description of matrix inequalities with, up to polynomial or rational change of variable, convex solution sets. Many of the methods employed are of a functional analytic nature, involving ideas and techniques from operator systems and spaces, specifically. Techniques and results from classical semialgebraic geometry, convex optimization, semidefinite programming, as well as several complex variables, are also used. A further objective of this project is the development, from the perspective of non-self-adjoint operator algebras, of tools and techniques useful in the study of function algebras. The Hardy space of bounded analytic functions on the unit disc is an example. In particular, an outcome will be a deeper understanding of the representations and contractive matrix-valued functions of such algebras. The techniques and methods employed are a blend of function theory, harmonic analysis, Riemann surface theory, operator theory, and the theory of operator algebras.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of this project was the further development of the theory of free semi-algebraic geometry with an emphasis on issues of convexity. The tools and techniques employed come from a variety of disciplines, including semi-algebraic geometry, several complex variables, operator systems and spaces, matrix convex sets and the theory of completely positive maps and dilations. 

Semi-algebraic geometry is the study of systems of polynomial inequalities in several variables.  Aside from their intrinsic mathematical interest, such systmes are ubiquitous in applications in optimization, science and engineering.  Free semi-algebraic geometry studies systems of, or more generally matrices of, inequalities involving non-commuting variables. These are known as matrix inequalities. Thus a matrix inequality (rational inequalities are of interest too) is described by a square matrix valued polynomial p in g non-commuting variables x=(x1,...,xg) (satisfying an additional symmetry condition) and written p>0. For free (matrix) polynomials, evaluation occurs not just on tuples of real numbers, but rather on tuples of symmetric square matrices (of the same size) X=(X1,...,Xg). For instance, in the case of two commuting variables, the polynomial p(x1,x2)= x1x2 - x2x1 evaluates to zero, but if, for a positive integer n, the  xj are replaced by n by n matrices Xj, then p(X1,X2)=X1 X2 - X2X1 need not be zero since matrix multiplication is not a commutative operation. The feasible set of  the matrix inequality p>0 is the set of g-tuples X of n by n matrices such that p(X) is a positive semidefinite matrix, where n is allowed to by any positive integer.  


Matrix inequalities arise in certain systems engineering problems. When worst case error analysis is paramount,  convexity of the feasible set is of fundamental importance since convexity insures that local optima are in fact global. In the case p has degree one, its feasible set is automatically convex and the inequality p>0 is a linear matrix inequality. The feasible set of a linear matrix inequality is a free spectrahedron. Earlier result of the PI showed, if the feasible set of a matrix inequality is bounded and convex, then it is in fact a free spectrahedron.  


In the case that the feasible set of p>0 is not convex, a natural strategy is to map - in a reasonable way - this non-convex set to a free spectrahedron. A major finding of this grant shows if such a map exists, then  it is essentially unique, except in some degenerate cases and certain rare cases in which the target linear matrix inequality has a highly algebraic structure. A long term goal is to determine exactly when such maps exist and automate the process of computing them.

A spectrahedron is the scalar solution set (g-tuples of 1 by 1 matrices) of a linear matrix inequality and thus is more general than a polytope. Spectrahedra appear in numerous applications, including optimization through semidefinite programming (a generalization of linear programming) and systems engineering. A basic, but difficult, problem is to determine if one spectrahedron is a subset of another. A finding of this grant is that the relaxation (approximation) obtained by considering free spectrahedra inclusions is tractable and has an elegant description in terms of operator systems and completely positive maps. The free inclusion problem can also be interpreted in terms of unital completely positive interpolation, which has implications for quantum information theory. 

A linear f map from the algebra Mn of n by n matrices to the algebra Mm of m by m matrices is positive if it sends positive matrices to positive matrices. It is completely positive if all its ampliations are positive; i.e., for each k the map f from Mk(Mn)  to Mk(Mm) given by f((Ti,j)) = (f(Ti,j)) is positive. The relative ratio of completely positive maps to positive maps is of considerable interest for both theoretical and practical reasons. For instance, maps that are positive, but not completely positive, can be used to test for entanglement in quantum systems in quantum information theory. An outcome of this grant are estimates on this ratio that are fine enough to show that it tends to zero when m and n tend to infinity. 


Further outcomes of this grant accrued to the foundations of free semialgebraic geometry. These included a study of the dual of a free spectrahedron. They turn out to be free spectrahedrops (projections of free spectrhedra) and an algebraic certificate for a free polynomial to take positive semidefinite values on a free spectrahedrop was determined. Results on approximating a non-convex feasible sets of matrix inequalities by its (matrix) convex hull (an alternative to mapping to a free spectrahedron in the absence of convexity) were established. A theory of convex hulls suitable for studying trace preserving (as opposed to unital) completely positive interpolation was developed.
